results.title: Best of British: Jaguar
results.creator_credit: Bruce Cox and Synchro Sports Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Best of British”.
An early Jaguar advertising slogan summed up the timeless appeal of this great British marque as ‘grace, space and pace’. This documentary explores these legendary qualities by taking a close look at all the significant Jaguar models, from the pre-war coach-built ‘special saloons’ through the SS100 and XK120, the E-type and XJ models, up to Britain’s first ‘supercar’- the XJ220. Interviews with Jaguar drivers such as Stirling Moss and Jack Fairman, and archival footage contribute to a fascinating review of Jaguar’s unique place in British motoring history.

results.title: Best of British: Bentley
results.creator_credit: Bruce Cox and Synchro Sports Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Best of British”.
In the twenties Bentley sports cars built up an enviable reputation for speed and reliability, with wins at Brooklands and record-breaking success at Le Mans. More than 75 years after its conception in 1919 Bentley’s original reputation for quality engineering and ‘luxury with sporting character’ is still intact. Using extensive archival footage, the program documents the early designs of W.O Bentley, the Bower Bentley’s and the Bentley 6. Also featured are interviews with Bentley collectors and a liberally illustrated history of the Bentley’s racing career.

results.title: Best of British: Aston Martin
results.creator_credit: Bruce Cox and Synchro Sports Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Best of British”.
The full story of Aston Martin begins in 1913 and continues through an uninterrupted pedigree of classic cars to the sleek DB7 and awesome V8 Vantage of today. This documentary examines in detail all the significant Aston Martin models from the past eighty years including the Brooklands racers from the 1920’s, the rare 1940 Atom, the ‘David Brown’ sports cars, the V8 models and the latest DB7 ‘supercharged sixes’.

results.title: Best of British: Triumph
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Best of British”.
Triumph is one of the greatest names in British motorcycle history. This documentary follows the story of the Triumph motorcycle from its beginnings in Coventry just after the turn of the century, to its resurrection in the late eighties. The turbulent history of the Triumph company is revealed through interviews with key figures associated with the Triumph name and significant Triumph models of the past and present are discussed in detail.

results.title: Best of British: MG
results.creator_credit: Bruce Cox and Syncro Sports Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Best of British”.
Twenty years after the MG factory was closed down, its parent company successfully revived the make. This documentary takes a detailed look at every signigicant MG ever made, from the earliest Midget in the twenties through the T-types, the MG-A and the company’s biggest seller so far, the MG-B. It also includes interviews with enthusiasts and designers, a visit to MG headquarters and rare archival footage of races and rallies.

results.title: Best of British: Rolls Royce
results.creator_credit: Bruce Cox and Synchro Sports Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Best of British”.
This documentary on the world’s most prestigious car maker, features all the significant Rolls-Royce models from the earliest Silver Ghost and classic Phantoms to the latest Silver Spirit and Flying Spur. A high percentage of all the Roll-Royces ever made are still in existence. Unique footage from the factory shows how the company applies the tradition and standards of almost 90 years of car manufacture to today’s technology.

results.title: American visions
results.brief_description: Written and presented by Robert Hughes, this 8 part series traces the development of America by following its art and architecture from Spanish settlement to the present day. A companian website to the series can be found at: http://www.pbs.org/wnet/americanvisions/menu.html

results.title: Age of anxiety
results.creator_credit: John Bush, Time Inc and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “American visions”.
The subject of Hughes’ final program is American art of the late twentieth century. The United States entered the 1960’s as a rich and powerful nation, confident in its virtuous destiny, but by the end of the decade the dreams were shattered. The terrible conflict of Vietnam divided the country as it had not been divided since the Civil War a century earlier. America’s “Age of Anxiety” had begun. Hughes looks at the “tableaux” of Ed and Nancy Reddin Kienholz, works that range across the whole canon of American public imagery. He tells the story of the klutzy images of blood-stained Ku Klux Klansmen in the paintings of Philip Guston. He also meets many of the artists; Eric Fischl, Bruce Nauman and Louise Bourgeois, whose work reflects the uncertain society of the late sixties and early seventies. Hughes argues that it was Ronald Reagan’s economic policies that created the art-market boom of the 1980’s, with inflated prices and inflated egos. He confronts one of the darlings of the decade, former bond dealer Jeff Koons, in the hope of finding something meaningful in a large sculpture of a crucified kitten in a sock. For Hughes, the eighties were “a low, dishonest time for much American art.” Written and presented by Robert Hughes.

results.title: The Empire of signs
results.creator_credit: Julia Cave, Time Inc and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “American visions”.
This episode deals with some of the truths and illusions in America’s development as a huge-scale cultural consumer from 1950 through the end of the 1970s. It can be seen, in retrospect, how cultural patterns follow changes of attitude socially and politically. “Having the bomb confirmed the old belief in American exceptionalism,” says Hughes. The last half of the twentieth century was to be “The American Century” and, between 1945 and the late 1960s, New York succeeded Paris as the Western world’s art capital. The American styles that carried its reputation were Abstract Expressionism. The work of Jackson Pollock, Willem de Kooning, Mark Rothko, Robert Motherwell, Barnett Newman and others, and its successor, Pop Art. The Pop Art movement was created by figures such as Robert Rauschenberg, Jasper Johns and Andy Warhol. Hughes considers how Abstract Expressionism and Pop Art fit into a global America of nuclear anxiety and chromium opulence, and what happens to the avant-garde when the pursuit of the new becomes America’s official culture. Written and presented by Robert Hughes.

results.title: Streamlines
results.creator_credit: James Kent, Time Inc and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “American visions”.
This episode covers American art and architecture from the Wall Street Crash to the eve of the Second World War. Even as Manhattan was on the verge of the Depression, the skyscraper reigned supreme. “New York’s shifting, rising skyline was like nothing Europe had ever seen”, notes Hughes, as he outlines Art Deco and describes the construction of the Chrysler Building and the Empire State Building. FDR’s New Deal employed artists through the WPA (Works Progress Administration), which itself was the center of controversy when Diego Rivera had his left-wing fresco painted over by capitalist tycoon John D. Rockefeller. Major projects such as the Hoover Dam, representing “a rallying symbol for American self-confidence, so bruised and battered by the Great Depression,” were constructed. Urban artists such as Jacob Lawrence, Edward Hopper and Stuart Davis are featured. In the American Midwest, artists evoked a more conservative perspective, depicting idyllic scenes of rural and farm life. Highly innovative design was used to sell consumers a modern lifestyle. This movement culminated with the exhibition dedicated to the modern machine, the New York World’s Fair of 1939, which is remembered today as the last burst of utopian belief in the machine before the destruction left by the military technology of World War II. Written and presented by Robert Hughes.

This episode covers American art and architecture from the Wall Street Crash to the eve of the Second World War. Even as Manhattan was on the verge of the Depression, the skyscraper reigned supreme. “New York’s shifting, rising skyline was like nothing Europe had ever seen”, notes Hughes, as he outlines Art Deco and describes the construction of the Chrysler Building and the Empire State Building. FDR’s New Deal employed artists through the WPA (Works Progress Administration), which itself was the center of controversy when Diego Rivera had his left-wing fresco painted over by capitalist tycoon John D. Rockefeller. Major projects such as the Hoover Dam, representing “a rallying symbol for American self-confidence, so bruised and battered by the Great Depression,” were constructed. Urban artists such as Jacob Lawrence, Edward Hopper and Stuart Davis are featured. In the American Midwest, artists evoked a more conservative perspective, depicting idyllic scenes of rural and farm life. Highly innovative design was used to sell consumers a modern lifestyle. This movement culminated with the exhibition dedicated to the modern machine, the New York World’s Fair of 1939, which is remembered today as the last burst of utopian belief in the machine before the destruction left by the military technology of World War II. Written and presented by Robert Hughes.
